page.title: 19Computers in Education
page.content: In 1985, every school in Cockermouth, infant through to secondary, had at least one microcomputer. Initially provided through a 50% grant from the D.T.I., many schools have bought further computers and peripherals (disc drives, printers etc.) from their own funds or with help from parents and local charitable organisations. Computers are used in a variety of ways, including C A L (Computer Assisted Learning), word processing and computer studies for examinations at secondary schools. Schools are obtaining software from commercial and educational sources. The M.E.P.(Micro-electronics Education Programme) (Government funded) has been helpful to schools. The Local Education Authority has advisory staff and seconded teachers who assist schools to use computers in education.
